In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Since 2000, world concern about the impacts of climate change, increasing scarcity of 
water, and, most recently, sharply higher and more volatile international food prices have grown 
rapidly. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will play catalytic roles in assisting Asia to both 
sustain food security and adapt to an environment of increasing scarcity and variability of fresh 
water  supply.  This  will  require  a  continuous  stream  of  new  knowledge  and  innovative 
operational  approaches  to  sustainable  water  and  land  management.  This  research  and 
development technical assistance (TA) will support the identification, assessment, and design of 
new  investments  for  more  sustainable,  water-efficient  irrigated  agriculture.  The  TA  was 
prepared in consultation with ADB’s South Asia Department, including the resident missions. 
The TA is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2020,1 which supports sustainable management of 
natural  resources  and  investments  in  water  systems  and  other  essential  public  services, 
particularly those that benefit the poor. The TA responds directly to ADB’s operational plan for 
sustainable  food  security  and  ADB’s  water  operational  plan  for  2011–2020,  which  call  for 
improving the productivity and efficiency of water use through (i) investing in modern irrigation 
infrastructure, (ii) adopting enabling policies that correctly price the opportunity cost of water, 
and (iii) strengthening institutions for more efficient and sustainable water management.2 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  By 2050, the world population may reach 9 billion. According to the Food and Agriculture 
Organization of the United Nations, up to 70% more food will be needed to match population 
growth and the impacts of consumer income growth and urbanization on food demand. This will 
place tremendous pressure on increasingly scarce land and water resources. Much of Asia, 
particularly South Asia and Central Asia, is highly vulnerable to climate change. Presently, 
about 80% of Asia’s fresh water is used for agriculture, but this is unlikely to be sustainable 
given the competing water demands of nonagricultural users and the environment and the 
increasing  variability  of  rainfall  due  to  the  impacts  of  climate  change.  By  2030,  40%  of 
developing Asia is projected to face a severe water shortage. Hence, there is a compelling need 
to identify and field test innovations that both conserve water and raise agricultural productivity.  
 
3.  In  irrigated  agriculture,  water  use  efficiency  usually  refers  to  the  amount  of  water 
effectively taken up by the crop as a percentage of the total water diverted into the irrigation 
system. Large losses of water are inevitable in conveyance and distribution, particularly in open 
unlined canals, as well as in field application. The overall efficiency of surface irrigation is low, 
although some of the percolation loss can be restored for crop and downstream uses via 
groundwater recharge and pumping. According to ADB’s water operational plan for 2011–2020, 
in most of Asia irrigation efficiency averages only 37%. This compares to levels of 45%–50% 
achieved in the more highly developed, water-scarce countries of the Mediterranean region.4 
Given the huge share of total water use for irrigation, a modest improvement in overall irrigation 
efficiency could potentially have a significant impact on water availability within a river basin.

4.  The areas actually irrigated in many systems are often much smaller than the command 
areas covered, reflecting poor system management and inadequate operation and maintenance, 
which lead to inequitable distribution of the available water among farmers near to and far from 
the  water  source.  Poor  timing  of  water  delivery  is  a  further  source  of  inefficiency.  Crop 
productivity suffers if water delivery does not match crop demands in both quantity and time. 
Furthermore, Asia’s irrigation water is rarely priced, rationed, or even measured by quantity, 
thus giving farmers little incentive to economize on using the water they actually receive. The 
difficulty of imposing water charges in surface irrigation will be a major challenge in efforts to 
raise water use efficiency, but some form of valuation may be essential if farmers are to adopt 
water-conserving crop practices. 
 
5.  Since 1980, groundwater has emerged as a major component of irrigation in many 
countries, including in many large-scale canal irrigation schemes. Any attempt to improve water 
use efficiency and productivity cannot focus solely on canal irrigation, but requires a broader 
perspective on conjunctive use and management of surface and groundwater. 
 
6.  Since most of Asia’s farmers are poor and operate small farms, suitable incentives are 
needed to assure farmers that water conservation will protect and, ideally, enhance rather than 
jeopardize their incomes. Equally important, based on the lessons of past international efforts in 
water conservation, widespread adoption of water-saving technologies will require a suitable 
institutional and policy environment, together with appropriate market-based incentives for all 
water  users  and  the  private  sector.  The  TA  will  seek  to  identify  viable,  location-specific 
technologies, management practices, policies, and institutional arrangements that are ready for 
pilot testing, replication, and scaling up in future ADB lending operations in South Asia.  
 
7.  Ideal study areas under the TA would have water systems where there is a significant 
degree of water scarcity, increasing competition for water between agriculture and other sectors, 
and strong local awareness of the need for action. Ideally, there would also be scope for water 
transfers between sectors and the potential for some form of water pricing or rationing to give all 
water  users  an  incentive  to  conserve  water.  Finally,  the  concerned  developing  member 
countries (DMCs) should have a significant program of proposed and ongoing ADB water 
operations  in  which  innovative  water-conserving  technologies,  policies,  and  institutional 
approaches can be pilot tested and, if successful, mainstreamed in future operations of ADB 
and other development partners.  
 
8.  Bangladesh, India, and Nepal have been chosen to participate in the TA because they 
possess these characteristics, are highly vulnerable to climate change, contain a high share of 
Asia’s rural poor, and share similar agroecological zones and farming systems. Further, the 
governments of the three countries prioritize water resource management in their respective 
country strategies. The India country partnership strategy, 2009–20125 gives an important role 
to agriculture growth, climate change adaptation, rural development, and water resources in line 
with the country’s Eleventh Five-Year Plan. ADB will assist in developing irrigation infrastructure 
to increase agricultural productivity, better water resources management between sectors and 
within each sector, and the resilience of agriculture to climate change. In Bangladesh, under the 
country strategy and program, 2006–2010,6 ADB supports efficient and sustainable irrigation to 
boost  agricultural  productivity  and  livelihood  diversification,  building  on  the  National  Water 
Policy and the National Water Management Plan. In Nepal, the country partnership strategy,

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be a more water-efficient and reliable (climate-change resistant) food 
supply in participating DMCs by 2020. Performance targets include (i) improved water efficiency 
in  target  irrigation  systems  with  crop  yield  increases  of  at  least  10%  compared  to  2012 
baselines in irrigation systems covering at least 100,000 hectares and in 50,000 poor farm 
households, and (ii) financing for more water-efficient irrigation of $500 million annually in South 
Asia  by  2017.  The  outcome  will  be  technically,  economically,  and  environmentally  sound 
technologies and associated institutional and policy frameworks ready for scaling up in future 
operations by ADB and other development partners. Specific deliverables are that future ADB 
operations will reflect the TA’s recommendations in the design of new ADB projects in the 
participating DMCs by 2017. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will involve two interrelated components: task 1 is a comprehensive synthesis of 
state-of-the-art knowledge and international best practices in water-efficient irrigated agriculture, 
including  preparation  of  a  detailed  analytical  framework  for  raising  water  use  efficiency  in 
irrigated agriculture in the different agroecosystems and irrigation domains of Asia.  
 
11.  Task 2 will involve country studies and capacity building to support the application of 
innovative  water-efficient  technologies  and  management  systems  in  the  design  and 
implementation of ADB investment projects in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal. In Bangladesh, 
ADB will support the proposed 2013 project for Piloting Improvement Management of Muhuri 
Irrigation, which will be the anchor for the TA activities. In India, the TA will focus on 2–3 major 
irrigation systems in water-stressed river basins assisted by ADB at the state level, and may 
also support states where ADB is assisting  with putting into operation the National Water 
Mission of the National Action Plan on Climate Change. In Nepal, the TA will be linked to the 
proposed 2013 Bagmati River Basin Improvement Project, which will focus on improving water 
security through integrated river basin management and increased water availability in the dry 
season. 
 
12.  The outputs will be (i) detailed plans for application of locally appropriate innovations in 
selected irrigation systems of the three DMCs; (ii) creation of capacity to monitor impacts of 
technology  adoption  and  management  on  water  use  efficiency  and  crop  productivity;  and 
(iii) dissemination  of  innovative  models  combining  technologies,  enabling  policies,  and 
institutional frameworks.  These outputs will be achieved through (i) evaluating emerging water-

saving technologies,8 policies, and institutional arrangements9 for replication in countries where 
water scarcity is an issue and specifically in the selected irrigation systems; (ii) identifying water 
allocation and incentive mechanisms to ensure that the new technologies lead to real water 
savings; analyzing the progress, performance, and prospects for private sector roles10 in water-
conserving agriculture; (iv) preparing location-specific guidelines for DMC policy makers to 
identify technologies, policies, and institutions for producing more food with less water under 
differing physical, economic, and agroecological conditions; (v) designing and costing project 
components  or  pilot  interventions  to  be  implemented  under  ADB  investment  projects;  (vi) 
establishing  performance  benchmarking  and  monitoring  systems,  and  training  provided  in 
selected  systems;  and  (vii)  technical  review  and  feedback  by  experts  and  policy  makers, 
together with knowledge dissemination within and outside of ADB. 
  
13.  Design of the TA assumes that concerns about climate change and water scarcity in 
Asia will prompt accelerated commitment to, and action on, needed reforms by all stakeholders. 
It is also assumed that future income growth in Asia will provide the market incentives for 
agricultural growth, including diversification into more water-efficient crops (e.g., vegetables and 
fruits) and cropping practices. In the participating DMCs, risks to the TA include lack of technical 
capacity and, especially in Bangladesh, lack of sufficient hydrological data for performance 
benchmarking. These risks are mitigated by (i) linking the TA to the preparation of ADB loans, 
which will involve required capacity building and policy dialogue; and (ii) undertaking a full year 
of data collection to establish the necessary baselines. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,440,000 equivalent, of which $1,400,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The 
International Water Management Institute (IWMI) will finance an equivalent of $40,000 for staff 
time, office space, and research and administrative support. Details are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. Because of the IWMI’s long track record 
and internationally recognized research work in water resources and irrigation, and its extensive 
network in South Asia, it will implement task 1. ADB will execute a memorandum of agreement 
with the IWMI describing the terms of reference, the detailed aspects of the research work, and 
IWMI’s responsibilities with respect to (i) timely delivery of quality outputs, (ii) regular monitoring 
and  evaluation  of  TA  results,  and  (iii)  reporting  and  other  communications.  An  inception 
workshop will be held about 2 months after approval of the TA to agree on a detailed work plan 
and  milestones  for  tasks  1  and  2.  The  IWMI  will  submit  the  following  reports  to  ADB: 
(i) inception report, (ii) semiannual progress reports, (iii) semiannual financial statements, (iv) 
audited annual financial statements, (v) draft final report, and (vi) final report. The inception

16.  For task 2, ADB, through the Regional and Sustainable Development Department and 
the South Asia Department, will be the implementing agency in coordination with concerned 
agencies of water resources, irrigation and agriculture in the participating DMCs. Before starting 
activities within a DMC, receipt of a no-objection letter from the government of such DMC will be 
required.  
 
17.  The TA will require an estimated 33.0 person-months of international consultants and 
63.5 person-months  of  national  consultants  in  the  areas  of  irrigation  management,  design, 
performance benchmarking, groundwater and conjunctive use, irrigation institutions and policy, 
participatory irrigation management, operation and maintenance, irrigated crop agronomy, and 
economics (Appendix 3). For task 1, IWMI will recruit on an individual basis, in consultation with 
ADB, 11.0 person-months of international and 2.5 person-months of national consulting services 
in the fields of irrigation policy, technology, management, institutions, groundwater irrigation, 
and economics. The curriculum vitae of proposed individual consultants will be approved by 
ADB before an individual consultant may be recruited by IWMI. For task 2, ADB will recruit on 
an individual basis the equivalent of 22 person-months of international consultants and 61 
person-months of national consultants. The Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
and the South Asia Department will jointly agree on the selection of the experts. The South Asia 
Department  will  supervise  the  individual  consultants  at  the  country  level  to  ensure  timely 
delivery of quality outputs. All consultants for tasks 1 and 2 will be engaged in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment, 
goods, and related services will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  All  equipment  will  be  turned  over  to  the  relevant 
participating government agencies upon completion of the TA. The TA will be implemented over 
a 2-year period to start in December 2011 and conclude in November 2013. 
 
18.  Outputs of the TA will include a major ADB knowledge product and individual country 
reports, which will be disseminated on ADB’s website; two regional seminars; and three high-
level national workshops to share the knowledge and lessons, and showcase the most highly 
successful  pilot  initiatives.  International  organizations  (such  as  the  Food  and  Agriculture 
Organization of the United Nations, the International Commission on Irrigation and Drainage, 
and the International Programme for Technology and Research in Irrigation and Drainage, 
among others) will be invited to the seminars and to provide critical review of the major TA 
reports. Within ADB, results of the TA will be disseminated through the communities of practice 
for water, and agriculture, rural development, and food security. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,400,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for Innovations for More Food with Less 
Water, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Task 1: Synthesis of Knowledge, International Experience, and Best Practices 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  develop  a  comprehensive  analytical  framework  for  raising  the 
efficiency and productivity of water use in irrigated agriculture. This framework will be based on 
a typology of Asia’s irrigated agricultural environments that is operationally relevant to the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The typology will distinguish the features that define the need for, 
and feasibility of (on technical, social, economic, policy and institutional dimensions) greater 
water efficiency and productivity in Asian agriculture, including  
(i)  the  degree  of  country-  and  basin-level  water  stress  (including  stress  from 
competition between sectors);  
(ii)  the nature of the main irrigation systems (large scale versus medium and small 
scale, surface water, and pumping);  
(iii)  the main crops grown (rice, wheat, and others), the intensity of cultivation, and 
the opportunities for new and more water-conserving crops based on market 
demand and value chain linkages;  
(iv)  socioeconomic conditions;  
(v)  seasonality of water supply, including groundwater resources;  
(vi)  the efficiency and control provided by the existing irrigation infrastructure and 
water management systems (including any transfers between sectors);  
(vii)  the policy environment, particularly regarding the strength of integrated water 
resources management, and participatory irrigation management; and  
(viii)  the extent to which economic instruments and market-based approaches are 
employed  to  regulate  the  use  of  irrigation  water,  including  a  review  of  the 
performance of various water pricing methods since the 1990s. 
 
2.  Ways to improve water efficiency and productivity will be addressed in the context of the 
following issues:  
(i)  impacts of water scarcity and competition between sectors in selected large-
scale irrigation systems, including an assessment of emerging institutional and 
policy responses;  
(ii)  opportunities  for  innovative  planning  and  management  practices  and  water-
saving technologies—at basin, system, and farm levels—for field testing and 
scaling up in countries and basins where water scarcity is an issue;  
(iii)  progress, performance, and prospects for the private sector and community and 
farmer organizations in water-conserving irrigation;  
(iv)  innovative enabling policies and institutional practices to realize water saving in 
farms;  
(v)  water-conserving agronomic practices for rice and rice–wheat systems; and  
(vi)  location-specific  options  and  associated  guidelines  for  developing  member 
country (DMC)  policy  makers  on  combinations  of technologies,  policies, and 
institutions to enhance the agricultural productivity of water use according to local 
physical, economic, social, and environmental conditions.  
 
3.  The consultants will prepare a synthesis report on international experience and best 
practices, showcasing the most promising initiatives. This report will complement the work of the 
country teams under task 2 (paras. 10–20) in identifying the most relevant approaches for 
ADB’s DMCs. Study findings will be presented in national and regional seminars to share 
experiences and lessons, and a summary knowledge product will be prepared identifying the

Appendix 3  11 
way forward for ADB in pursuing the most attractive approaches in future lending and technical 
assistance  (TA)  operations. The International Water  Management Institute (IWMI)  will  also 
coordinate with the Task 2 experts working at the country level (paras. 10–20). The IWMI will 
engage, on an individual basis and in coordination with ADB, about 11.0 person-months of 
international and 2.5 person-months of national consulting services in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) based on the 
following terms of reference. 
 
1.  Team Leader in Irrigation Technology and Policy (international, 3 person-
months) 
4.  The team leader will  
(i)  coordinate with ADB and the country teams, and provide overall direction to the 
IWMI study, guide all individual researchers, and take overall responsibility for 
the quality of the study’s final report;  
(ii)  review and synthesize the literature from Asia and other regions as relevant on 
improvement  of  water  use  efficiency  and  water  productivity  in  irrigated 
agriculture; 
(iii)  assess the  options  available  for  efficiency  improvement  and  synthesize  best 
practices that can be adopted in the Asian context;  
(iv)  develop  an  analytical  framework  for  raising  water  use  efficiency  in  irrigated 
agriculture, covering  the  technological,  institutional,  and  policy  dimensions of 
Asia’s large-scale irrigation systems; and  
(v)  develop  recommendations  for  investment  and  financing  priorities  for  ADB  to 
promote greater efficiency and productivity of irrigation water use. 
 
2.  Principal  Researcher  in  Irrigation  Management  (international,  2  person-
months) 
5.  The researcher will  
(i)  synthesize international best practices in efficient management of large irrigation 
systems involving the public sector, participatory irrigation management, and the 
private sector;  
(ii)  prepare case studies of good policies and practices in planning and establishing 
irrigation management systems; and  
(iii)  identify requirements for policy reform, capacity building, and training that need 
to  be  investigated  in  the  design  of  ADB  projects  to  ensure  an  appropriate 
incentive framework for water-conserving irrigation and on-farm crop practices. 
 
3.  Groundwater  Economics  and  Policy  Specialist  (international,  5  person-
months) 
6.  The specialist will  
(i)  synthesize international knowledge on conjunctive uses of groundwater in Asia’s 
major irrigation systems, focusing on policies and system management practices 
that contribute to efficient groundwater abstraction;  
(ii)  assess  best  practices  in  conjunctive  use  as  one  element  of  water-efficient 
management of large-scale systems; and  
(iii)  develop  recommendations  for  investment  and  financing  priorities  for  ADB  to 
improve the efficiency and equity of groundwater use, raise farmer incomes, and 
reduce the adverse environmental impacts of groundwater overdraft.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
 
4.  Rice Cropping Systems Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
7.  The specialist will  
(i)  synthesize international knowledge on water-conserving agronomic and varietal 
practices for irrigated rice and the rice–wheat system, focusing on the trade-offs 
(if any) between crop water consumption, yields, and farmer income; and  
(ii)  synthesize the experience in introducing and adopting these practices, identifying 
critical  system  and  on-farm  constraints,  and  needs  for  future  policy  action, 
research, and extension outreach. 
 
5.  Irrigation Economist (national, 2.5 person-months) 
8.  The economist will  
(i)  synthesize international experience in the use of water pricing or other market-
based approaches to regulate the use of irrigation water, including a review of 
the performance of various water pricing methods since the 1990s; and  
(ii)  initiate and provide methodological guidance to the TA research assistants in the 
economic  analyses  of  the  net  benefits  of  innovative  irrigation  and  crop 
management practices that promote water use efficiency at the farm, system, 
and basin levels.  
 
6.  Research Assistants 
9.  Task 1 also provides for research assistants, under the supervision of the experts, to 
undertake data collection, analysis, and report writing in irrigation management, technology, and 
institutions, participatory irrigation, groundwater, economics, rural sociology, and other areas as 
required.  
 
B.  Task 2: Country- and Project-Specific Recommendations and Pilot Initiatives 
 
10.  Task 2 will involve country-level investigations, capacity building, and pilot testing to 
support the application of innovative water efficient technologies and management systems in 
the design and implementation of ADB investment projects in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal.  A 
detailed description of the nature and forms of TA support in irrigated water resource projects in 
these three countries are provided in Supplementary Appendix A (available upon request).  
 
11.  For  task  2,  ADB  will  engage  22  person-months  of  international  consultants  and 
61 person-months of national consultants on an individual basis. Identification and selection of 
suitable experts as well as supervision and monitoring of their activities and delivery of outputs 
at  the  country  level  will  be  done  jointly  by  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development 
Department and the project officers for the specific projects, who in turn will consult local 
government authorities. The indicative terms of reference are described in paras. 12–20 but will 
be discussed in more detail during the inception phase.  
 
1.  Country Team Leaders (international, 6 person-months) 
12.  The team leaders will have specialized technical expertise as needed in each country. 
They will provide overall direction to the country teams and ensure integration with ongoing ADB 
project design activities. They will provide technical leadership in investigating the specific

Appendix 3  13 
issues in the irrigated water resource projects in Bangladesh, India, and Nepal (Supplementary 
Appendix A [available upon request]). In each country, the leaders will  
(i)  guide the technical, institutional, and policy assessments;  
(ii)  recommend specific practical innovations for more efficient water use for possible 
incorporation into ADB project design;  
(iii)  guide the preparation of proposed project components; and  
(iv)  recommend pilot testing and additional studies and surveys as needed to ensure 
comprehensive project preparation. 
 
2.  Irrigation  Management  Specialists  (Bangladesh,  India,  and  Nepal: 
international, 3 person-months; national, 12 person-months) 
13.  The specialists will  
(i)  examine  the  nature  and  efficiency  of  existing  groundwater  and  conjunctive 
irrigation and prepare pilot models and management approaches (Bangladesh);  
(ii)  make  a  synthesis  of  country  efforts  to  enhance  water  use  efficiency  in  2–3 
irrigation systems (India); and  
(iii)  analyze the potential for greater conjunctive use of surface and groundwater in 
the basin’s lower reaches and the scope for improving water use efficiency in 
farmer-managed schemes in the basin’s upper reach (Nepal).  
 
3.  Participatory Irrigation Specialist (Bangladesh: international, 4 person-months) 
14.   The specialist will review successful participatory approaches to irrigation and water 
resource management, lessons  learned,  and  challenges.  In the  review,  particular  attention 
should be given to the key actors or stakeholders that have the greatest impact or the biggest 
role in participatory irrigation management. The specialist will then identify options that can be 
pilot tested to improve the management of the Muhuri Irrigation Project in Bangladesh. 
 
4.  Irrigation Planning and Design Engineers (India and Nepal: international, 1 
person-month; national, 8 person-months) 
15.  The engineers will contribute in the synthesis of country efforts to enhance water use 
efficiency in 2–3 irrigation systems (India), and help study the potential for greater conjunctive 
use of surface and groundwater in the basin’s lower reaches and the scope for improving water 
use efficiency in farmer-managed schemes in the basin’s upper reach (Nepal).  
 
5.  Irrigation  Operation  and  Maintenance  Specialists  (India  and  Nepal: 
international, 2 person-months; national, 6 person-months) 
16.  The specialists will  
(i)  review current operation and maintenance procedures and arrangements;  
(ii)  analyze deficiencies and impact on water users’ associations on selected pilot 
schemes; and 
(iii)  identify key problems and tailor-made opportunities for improvement including 
institutional, legal, organizational, and policy changes.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
6.  Institutional  and  Water  Users’  Association  Specialists  (India  and  Nepal: 
international, 2 person-months; national, 9 person-months) 
17.  The specialists will conduct the institutional and water users’ association assessment at 
country levels (in cooperation with the IWMI). On selected pilot schemes, they will analyze the 
strengths and weaknesses of the institutions, and identify opportunities for improvement. 
 
7.  Agriculture  Specialists  (India  and  Nepal:  international,  3  person-months, 
national, 10 person-months) 
18.  The specialists will review current country agricultural and water policies and instruments 
(economic,  social)  and  identify  core  elements  that  may  affect  or  encourage  water  users’ 
associations and water productivity. On the selected pilot schemes, they will (i) assess current 
on-farm irrigation (field application) and agricultural strategies and practices; and (ii) identify key 
practices that negatively affect water productivity and their impact on small farmers’ productivity 
and incomes. Through participatory methods, identify key drivers required to initiate changes in 
practices that lead to increased water productivity.  
 
8.  Project Economists (India and Nepal: international, 1 person-month; national, 4 
person-months) 
19.  The economists will conduct economic analysis of the management of irrigation systems 
in India and the proposed basin improvement project in Nepal, and consolidate the findings in 
both countries. 
 
9.  Survey Specialist (Bangladesh: national, 12 person-months) 
20.  The  specialist  will  develop  a  survey  design  to  collect  baseline  data,  manage  the 
implementation of the survey (including logistics and enumerators), and analyze the survey 
results.
